b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:39): You must be *really* bored...
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:40): Given how many people are implementing it, it'd be kind of nice if there was some interoperability, and currently there isn't much
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:46): http://philip.html5.org/docs/rdfa/ - in how many ways is this horridly broken and/or rubbish?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:50): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: you should join the xhtml2 wg and rewrite all their specs
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:51): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: That doesn't seem especially useful for all of them, only for ones that are being actively used :-p
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:51): Also, that would be too much work and I'd get bored before then
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:52): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: you should join the xhtml2 wg and rewrite all their specs that are being actively used until you get bored
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:52): The latter condition would only last for a few days, I expect
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:53): wait, didn't you start doing this because you were bored?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:54): and soon I'll think of something else to do instead
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:54): (That occasion might coincidentally coincide with the release of the TF2 sniper/spy update)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:58): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: should "valid URL" be "valid URL that is an absolute URL"?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:00): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: Apparently not, as far as I can tell from http://www.w3.org/TR/rdfa-syntax/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:01): It talks about resolving all URIs, and doesn't say they have to be absolute

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:01): even for xmlns - "Note that it is generally considered a good idea not to use relative paths in namespace declarations, but since it is possible that an author may ignore this guidance, it is further possible that the URI obtained from a CURIE is relative. However, since all URIs must be resolved relative to [base] before being used to create triples, the use of relative paths should not have any effect on processing."
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (19:02): seems silly to allow relative urls imho :)
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:02): the relative paths in xmlns thing was a huge war in XML land, about 9 nears ago...
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:03): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: I agree :-)
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:03): "seems silly to allow relative urls" is a good summary :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:03): This isn't just about xmlns, though
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:04): It includes things like <div about="#me">
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:04): which I suppose you do want to allow relative URLs for
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:04): but re xml, this did blow up. http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/xml-uri/  http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/xml-uri/2000May/
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:04): (...1700 messages in two months)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:05): I guess it's impossible to require anything of xmlns values, but requiring CURIEs to be absolute (after prefix processing) seems sane
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:06): plus a few offlist i'm sure :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:06): public-html had 1773 in *one* month :-)

c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:06): i consider rdfa with curies to be about as fragile as Javascript ... but without the built-in "aw crap it doesn't work, what did I screw up?" corrective that comes with separating .js usage from .js declarations

c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:07): ...so i think we need some utilities that replace that part of the lifecycle. "aww crap it doesn't work in google/yahoo" might operate the same, if their indexes updated in real time or there were better checkers...
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:08): Or just an HTML validator?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:08): Hmm, someone needs to invent a real-time search engine indexer update protocol
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:08): there are so many ways of making technically valid stuff that's still not v useful
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:09): but yeah, integration with normal validation ideally
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:09): Maybe you could set up an <event-source> server that the indexers connect to, so you can immediately send them all your updates
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:09): http://www.sitemaps.org/ is sorta related, but i guess those sitemaps are just periodically polled
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:10): What kinds of problems would still be technically valid?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:10): Typos in namespace URIs is the obvious one, I suppose
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:10): using an unfashionable property or old style URI
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:10): (I'm assuming the validator would be clever enough to detect references to undeclared prefixes etc)

c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:11): eg. if someone validates using http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.0/Creator I'd like an easy way for them to learn that http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.0/creator is more widely used, and http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/creator even more widely used
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:11): (similar things hold for microformat idioms, since different constructs become fashionable over time, or are consumed by different apps)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:13): (Quite a few of the errors in http://philip.html5.org/data/rdf-namespace-status.txt are just plain typos - people find these things unusually tricky)
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:15): rdf-namespace-status.txt is cool
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:15): i had a script somewhere that tried to extract from dns/whois the time left for each popular domain
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:16): was quite fiddly as i recall, maybe there's a better library out there to try somewhere
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:16): whois+grep? :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:17): Hmm, I guess they're not a very consistent format
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:18): xmlns.com appears to have its whois information in YAML
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:18): (via Gandi)
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:19): whois+grep --- yeah exactly what i was doing initially
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:19): then i think i found some perl api
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:19): yaml, cool hadn't seen that
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:20): so one issue is figuring out from the domain "xxx.yyy.zzz.aaa.bbb.ccc" which one to look up
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:20): Hmm, good point
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:20): foo.co.uk you look up foo.co.uk
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:20): foo.co.com you look up co.com ...
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:20): http://publicsuffix.org/ seems too much like hard work
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:20): yeah that's the site i was just thinking of
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:21): i guess you can crawl down and look 'em all up
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:21): What did you want that data for?
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:21): i'd like to make a "health check" site for namespaces, ... so people have some sense of QA before they commit to using one

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:21): I guess most people would leave it until the last minute before renewing their registration, and it's hard to tell the difference between that and an abandoned domain

c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:22): 'cos it's all well and good being decentralised, but not if it's going to leave holes in the data in 10 years time cos someone's random experiment accidentally got worldwide use
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:22): last minute - yeah, also i'm told some registrars (eg. in Germany) don't let you register lots of years
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:22): You could solve that problem by putting the RDF schema in a data: URL and use that as the namespace, instead of http://
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:23): so for eg dbpedia.org seemed to be perillously close to expiration, but the owner/admin had it on some rolling auto-debit arrangement
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:23): heh, that'll really help with our consiseness problem :)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:24): Then you could define that namespace URI as an entity in an external DTD
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:24): and import that into your document and use the entity reference
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:24): which would avoid verbosity
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:25): Then anyone publishing a vocabulary can put a DTD containing their schema data: URI onto their server
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:25): The advantage is that you can move it onto a different host without changing the namespace that your data uses
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:26): The disadvantage is that it's clearly a stupid idea
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:26): how could the schema reference the properties defined within it?
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:26): btw http://prefetch.net/code/domain-check looks handy
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:27): I guess it could still reference them with "#"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:27): If it wants to reference anything in another schema, it can just import that schema's DTD
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:28): it's mad but worth writing up!
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:29): Also it ties in nicely to the discussion on the WHATWG list about having browsers download external DTDs
c8418bd17d6b1d70bf83c9f1c1664266 (19:29): gotta run (eats...)
